title: Diagnosed With Food Allergies -- Now What?

content: What are the girls going to eat? Did we pack the snacks? Did we grab the EpiPens? I ask myself these three questions every single time I leave the house with my girls, who have multiple food allergies. When we planned to start our family, carrying an EpiPen did not quite fall on that list, but neither did having food allergies.

I remember when we first found out. Cali, my 7-year-old daughter, was 4 months old at the time and we could not get rid of the eczema that had taken over her body. The medication was not working, and I was feeling defeated watching her scratch all day to the point she would bleed. The ice and all of the internet recommendations were not enough. During the same time, I was having trouble nursing, so I wanted to give her formula to help supplement. Worst decision I made. My 4-month-old baby projectile vomited all the way across the room. I knew I had to do something.

content: I scheduled an appointment with the allergist immediately. We were not prepared for her to come back with more than six food allergies. Surprisingly, in an odd way, I was relieved that we found a solution to one problem but shattered only to discover an entirely new world that I knew nothing about.

As a mom, we find these superpowers for our children that we do not have for ourselves. I read books on food allergies, I found every article on the market, I joined support groups, and I became part of this unwanted club.

I then found myself being a part of this club twice with my second daughter. Now a “pro” food allergy mom. I got this, right? I know I have to bring my own food to birthday parties or other social gatherings. I know I have to call restaurants ahead of time to make sure they have something on the menu for us to eat. I know I have to ensure all caretakers understand what my girls can and cannot eat and how to treat an allergic reaction. I know how to read ALL food labels. I know I have to bring a doctor’s note for certain venues or certain travel destinations. I know I cannot take my youngest daughter to a seafood restaurant because just the smell of seafood causes her to have an allergic reaction. Do I have this? I cannot afford not to.

content: What is it like being a mom of children with multiple food allergies? It is a world full of planning and research tagged with anxiety. But it is also a world full of exploring alternative ways to enjoy life experiences. I’ve learned how to have fun without involving food, I’ve learned some great food alternatives that I would not have tried otherwise, and I’ve learned how to become an advocate for my daughters.

My goal for my daughters is to live life to the fullest and not defined by their food allergies. We can easily get consumed in what we cannot eat, but we focus more on what we can eat and eat it all up. I like to apply this same motto to all aspects of life.
